titleStmt.title: Analysis of the Examples in Mudulation
titleStmt.author: Reger, Max

div.head: 1) G-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; use this C-major which is at the same time the sub-dominant for G-major. (Cadence!)

[CI, (= GIV), GII,*)
GV46, GV, | GI]

div.head: 2) D-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relativ (e-minor) to the dominant (G-major) of C-major; use this e-minor (1st inversion), which ist also relative to the sub-dominant (G-major) of D-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CIII (= DII, DV64, DV,| DI]

div.head: 3) A-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (d-minor) to the sub-dominant (F-major) of C-major; use this d-minor, which ist at the same time the minor sub-dominant of A-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CII (= AIV♮ ), | AV64, AV, | AI]

div.head: 4) E-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (a-minor) to the tonic of C-major; use this a-minor, which is at the same time the minor sub-dominant of E-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CIV (= EIV♮ ), EV64, EV, | EI]

div.head: 5) ♭-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relarive (e-minor) to the dominant (G-major) of C-major; use this e-minor which is also the minor sub-dominant in ♭-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CIII (= HIV0), HV64 H V, | HI]

div.head: 6) F#-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; dominant G-major; the 1st inversion of which ist used (the chord of the sixth, b d g), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth *) in F#-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CV (= FisIV6♮ ♮ ), FisV64, FisV, | FisI]

div.head: 7) C#-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (e-minor) to the dominant (G-major) of C-major; use this e-minor, which is also the minor sub-dominant of ♭-major: use this F#-major, which is at the same time sub-dominant in C#-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CIII, (= HIV♮) HV (= CisIV), CisV, | CisI]

div.head: 8) G#-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (d-minor) to the sub-dominant (F-major) of C-major; dominant (A-major) of d-minor; use the 1st inversion of this A-major (the chord of the sixth, c# e a), which is also the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in G#-major. (Cadence!=

[CI, CII,(= dI*)
dV#, (= GisIV6♮♮) | GisV× GisI]

div.head: 9) D#-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (d-minor) to the subdominant (F-major) of C-major; use this d-minor, which is at the same time sub-dominant of a-minor; dominant (E-major) of a-minor; use the 1st inversion of this E-major (the chord of th sixth g# b e), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in D#-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CII (= aIV), aV# , aV# (= DisIV6♮ ♮ ) | DisV DisV× DisI]

div.head: 10) A#-major,
div.p: Tonic C-mayor; relative (a-minor) to the tonic C-major; use this a-minor, which is at the same time sub-dominant in e-minor; dominant (♭-major) of e-minor; use the 1st inversion of this ♭-major (the chord of the sixth, d# f# b), which is also the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in A#-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CVI (= eIV), eV# , eV# (= AisIV6# ♮ | AisV64, AisV× , AisI.]

div.head: 11) E#-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (e-minor) to the dominant (G-major) of C-major; use this e-minor, which is also sub-dominant in b-minor; dominant (F#-major) of b-minor; use the 1st iversion of this F#-major (the chord of the sixth, a# c# f#), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in E#major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CIII (= hIV), hV# , hV# (= EisIV6# # ), | EisV64, EisV× EisI]

div.head: 12) B#-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (e-minor) to the dominant (G-major) of C-major; use this e-minor, which is also sub-dominant in b-minor; dominant (F#-major) of b-minor; use this F#-major, which is at the same time the tonic of F#-major; domianant (C#major) (1st inversion) of F#-major; use this chord of the sixth (e# g# c#), which is also the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in B#-major: (Cadence!)
[CI, CIII (= hIV) hV# (= FisI) FisV (= HisIV6# # | HisV64, HisV× HisI]

div.head: 13) F-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (d-minor) to the sub-dominant (F-major) of C-major; use this d-minor, which is also relative to the tonic of F-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CII (= FVI), FII7, FV, | FI]

div.head: 14) B(flat)-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; use this C-major, which is at the same time the 2nd super-dominant *) ) of B♭-major; dominant (F-major) of B♭-major; tonic B♭-major.
[CI (= BVv), BV7, BI]

div.head: 15) E♭-major.
div.p: TTonic C-major; minor sub-dominant (f-minor, 1st inversion) of C-major; use this f-minor, which is also relative to the sub-dominant (A♭-major) of E♭-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CIV♭, (= EsII) EsV64, EsV53, | EsI]

div.head: 16) A♭-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f ab db) in C-major; use this chord of the sixth, which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the sub-dominant (D♭-major) of A♭-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CIV6♭♭ (= AsIV), AsV64, AsV53, | AsI]

div.head: 17) D♭-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major, chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f ab db) in C-major; use this chord of the sixth (f ab db), which is also the 1st inversion of the tonic of D♭-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CIV6♭♭ (= DesI), DesIV, DesV, | DesI]

div.head: 18) G♭-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixtn (f ab db) in C-major; use this chord of the sixth (f ab db), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (D♭-major) of G♭-major. (Cadence!)
[CI, CIV6♭♭ (= GesV, | GesIV, GesV, | GesI]

div.head: 19) C♭-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f ab db) in C-major; use this chord of the sixth (f ab db), which is at the same time, the 1st inversion of the 2nd super-dominant (D♭-major) of C♭-major; dominant (G♭-major, 64 53) of C♭-major; tonic C♭-major.
[CI, CIV6♭♭ (= CesVv ), CesV64, CesV53, | CesI ]

div.head: 20) F♭-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f ab db) in C-major; use this chord of the sixth (f ab db), which is also the 1st inversion of the dominant (D♭-major) of gb-minor; use this gb-minor, which is at the same time relative to the sub-dominant (Bb♭-major) of F♭-major; dominant C♭-major; tonic F♭-major.
[CI, CIV6♭♭ (= gesV♮ ), gesI, (=FesII) | FesV FesI]

div.head: 21) Bb♭-major.
div.p: Tonic C-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f ab db) in C-major; use this chord of the sixth (f ab db), which is at the same time, the 1st inversion (chord of the sixth) of the dominant (D♭-major) of G♭-major; use this G♭-major, which is at the same time the dominant of cb-minor; use this cb-minor, which is also relative to the sub-dominant (Eb♭-major) of Bb♭-major; dominant 64 53 (F♭-major) of Bb♭-major; tonic Bbb major.
[CI, CIV6♭♭ (= GesV), GesI (= cesV), cesI (= HesesII) | HesesV64, HesesV53 HesesI]

div.head: 22) a-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (d-minor) to the sub-dominant (F-major) of C-major; use this d-minor, which is at the same time the sub-dominant of a-minor. (Cadence!)
[CI, CII (= aIV) aV64 aV# | aI]

div.head: 23) e-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (a-minor) to the tonic of C-major; use this a-minor, which is also the sub-dominant in e-minor. (Cadence!)
[CI, CVI (= eIV), eV64 eV# | eI]

div.head: 24) b-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; use the 1st inversion of this C-major (the chord of the sith, e g c), which is at the same time chord of the Neapolitan sixth in b-minor. (Cadence!)
[CI CI = (hIV6♮ ) hV64 hV# | hI]

div.head: 25) f#-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; 1st inversion of the dominant (G-major) of C-major; use this chord of the sixth (b d g), which is at the same time the Neapolitan sixth in f#-minor. (Cadence!)
[CI, CV (= fisIV6♮ , fisV64, fisV7# , | fisI]

div.head: 26) c#-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; domiannt ( G.major) of C-major; use this Gmajor, which is also the sub-dominant of D-major; use this D-major (arranged a schord of the sixth), as it is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f# a d) in c#-minor. (Cadence!)
CI, CV (= DIV), DI (= cisIV6♮ ) cisV# | cisI]

div.head: 27) g#-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (d-minor) to the sub-dominant of C-major; use this d-minor, which is also tonic in d-minor; then dominant (A-major) of d-minor; this A-major (arranged as chord of the sith c# e a) is used, as it is at the same time the chor of the Beapolitan sixth in g#-minor. (Cadence!)
[CI, CII (= dI), dV# (= gisIV6♮ ), gisV× , | gisI]

div.head: 28) d#-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (a-minor) to C-major; use this a-minor, which is also tonic in a-minor; dominant (E-major) of a-minor, (as chord of the sixth), which chord of the sixth (g# b e) is used, as it is at the same thime the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in d#-minor. (Cadence!)
[CI, CVI, (= a I), aV# (= disIV6♮ ) disV× , | disI]

div.head: 29) a#-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; relative (a-inor) to the tonic (C-major); use this a-minor, which is at the same time sub-dominant in e-minor; dominant (♭-major) of e-minor; use the 1st inversion of this ♭-major (the chord of the sixth d# f# b), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in a#-minor. (Cadence!)
[CI, CVI (= eIV) eV# , eV# (= aisIV6♮ ) | aisV64 aisV× aisI]

div.head: 30) e#-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; take the 1st inversion (chord of the sixth) of this; use this chord of the sixth (e g c), which is also the chord of the Beapolitan sixth in ♭-major; dominant (F#-major) of ♭-major; take this F#-major in tis 1st inversion, (chord of the sixth a# c# f#), i. e. this chord of the sixth is used, as it is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in e#-minor. (Cadence!)

div.head: 31) b#-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; dominant (G-major) of C-major; this G-major arranged as chord of the sixth (b d g) is used, which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in F#-major; dominant (C#-major) of F#-major, which C#-major; dominant (C#major) of F#-major; which C#-major is, arranged in the 1st inversion, the chord of the sixth (e# g# c#); use this chord of the sixth (e# g# c#), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in b#-minor. (Cadence!)

div.head: 32) d-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major = the dominant of F-major; relative (g-minor) to the sub-dominant of F-major; use this g-minor, which is at the same time the sub-dominant in d-minor. (Cadence!)
[CI (= FV), FII (= dIV) dV64 dV# | dI]
(phrygisch!)

div.head: 33) g-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major, which is used, as it is also the chord of the Dorian *) sixth in g-minor; dominant (D-major) with 7th (2nd inversion) of g-minor.
[CI (= gIV3♮ ) gV7# gI]

div.head: 34) c-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; minor sub-dominant (f-minor) in C-major; use this f-minor, which is at the same time the sub-dominant fo c-minor. (Cadence!)
[CI, CIV♭ (= cIV) cV64, cV♮ , | cI]

div.head: 35) f-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major is used, as it is also the dominant in f-minor; then Cadence.
[CI (= fV♮ ), fI, fII, fV♮ | fI]

div.head: 36) bb-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major is used, which is at the same time the 2nd super-dominant in bb-minor; dominant (f a c [eb]) in bb-minor.
[CI (= bVv) bV7♮ , bI]

div.head: 37) eb-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; minor sub-dominant (f-minor) in C-major; use this f-minor (f ab c), which is also the chord of the Dorian sixth in eb-minor; dominant (♭-major) of eb-minor and tonic eb-minor.

div.head: 38) ab-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; chord of the Beapolitan xixth (f ab db) in C-major; use this chord of the sixth (f ab db), which is at the same time the Dorian sixth (D♭-major as chord of the sixth) in ab-minor; dominant (E♭-major) and tonic of ab-minor

div.head: 39) db-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f ab db) in C-major; which chord of the sixth (f ab db) is used, as it ist at the same time the sub-dominant of A♭-major; dominant (E♭-major) of A♭-major; tonic of A♭-major with minor seventh, which Ab-chord of the seventh (ab c eb gb) is used, as it is also the dominant of db-minor.
[CI, CIV66♭♭ (= AsIV), AsV7, AsI7♭ (= desV7♭) | desI]

div.head: 40) g♭-minor.
div.p: Tonic C-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f a♭ d♭) in C-major, which chord of the sixth ist used, as it is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant D♭-major (with seventh c♭, i. e. 66) of g♭-minor; tonic g♭-minor.
[CI CIV6♭♭ (= gesV♮ ), gesV7♮ , | gesI]

div.head: 41) c♭-minor
div.p: Tonic C-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f a♭ d♭) in C-major, which chord of the sixth is used, as it is also the dominant (D♭-major with seventh c♭, i. e. 65) of G♭-major, and this G♭-major again is used, as it is at the same time the dominant of c♭-minor; tonic c♭-minor.
[CI, CIV 6♭♭ (= Ges V(7♭)), Ges I (= ces V♭) | ces I]

div.head: 42) E♭-major(e♭-minor).
div.p: Tonic C#-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f# a d) in C#-major; use this chord of the sixth, which is at the same time the 1st inversion of D-major, the 2nd super-dominant of c-minor; dominant (G-major) of c-minor; sub-dominant (f-minor) of c-minor; use this f-minor, which is also relative to the sub-dominant (A♭-major) of E♭-major. (Cadence!)
NB. To modulate to e♭-minor, use the f-minor (f a♭ c), which is also the chord of the Dorian sixth in e♭-minor; dominant (B♭-major) of e♭-minor. (Cadence!)
[CisI, Cis IV6♮♮(=cVV5♮#), cV♮, cIV(=EsII), EsV,| EsI]
[CisI, Cis IV6♮♮(=cVV5♮#), cV♮, cIV(= esII5♮), esV♮| esI]

div.head: 43) A♭-major (a♭-minor).
div.p: Tonic C#-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f# a d) in C#-major; use this chord of the sixth, which is at the same time the 1st inversion of D-major, the 2nd super-dominant of c-minor; dominant (G-major), tonic (c-minor) of c-minor; use this c-minor, as it is also relative to the dominant (E♭-major) of A♭-major (or a♭-minor); tonic A♭-major (or a♭-minor).
[CisI, CisIV6♮♮(= c Vv5♮#) cV♮, cI(= AsIII) AsV, | AsI]
[CisI, CisIV6♮♮(= c Vv 5♮#) c V♮, cI(= AsIII) asV( ♮)| asI]

div.head: 44) D♭-major (d♭-minor),
div.p: Tonic C#-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f# a d) in C#-major; use this chord of the sixth (f# a d), which is at the same time 2nd super-dominant in c-minor (1st inversion of this 2nd super-dominant); dominant (G-major), tonic (c-minor) of c-minor; sub-dominant (f-minor) of c-minor, which f-minor is used, as it is also relative to the dominant (A♭-major) of D♭-major (d♭-minor); dominant (A♭-major) of D♭-major (d♭-minor); tonic D♭-major (d♭-minor).
[CisI, CisIV6 ♮ ♮(= cVv5♮#),cV ♮, cI, cIV(= DesIII) DesV| DesI]
[CisI, CisIV6 ♮ ♮(= cVv5♮#),cV ♮, cI, cIV(= DesIII) desV ♮| desI]

div.head: 45) G♭-major (g♭-minor).
div.p: Tonic C#-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f# a d) in C#-major; use this chord of the sixth, which is at the same time the 2nd super-dominant (1st inversion of this 2nd super-dominant) of c-minor; dominant (G-major), sub-dominant (f-minor) of c-minor; use this f-minor, which is also relative to the dominant (A♭-major) of D♭-major; sub-dominant (G♭-major) of D♭-major; use the tonic with 7♭ (D♭-major), which is at the same time dominant in G♭-major (g♭-minor).
[CisI, CisIV6♮♮(= cVv#♮) cV♮, cIV(= DesIII| DesIV, DesI♭(= GesV7♭ GesI
[CisI, CisIV6♮♮(= cVv#♮) cV ♮, cIV(= DesIII| DesIV, DesI♭(= gesV7♭♮ gesI

div.head: 46) C♭-major (c♭-minor).
div.p: Tonic C#-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (f# a d) in C#-major; use this chord of the sixth (f# a d), which is also the 2nd super-dominant (1st inversion) of c-minor, which is at the same time relative to the dominant (Aϗ-major) of Dϗ-major; sub-dominant (Gϗ-major) of Dϗ-major; use this Gϗ-major, which is also the dominant of Cϗ-major (cϗ-manor).
[CisI CisIV6♮♮(= cVv5♮#) cV cIV(= DesIII) DesIV (= CesV)| CesI]
[CisI CisIV6♮♮(= cVv5♮#) cV cIV(= DesIII) DesIV (= cesV♮)|cesI]
NB. The modulations in Nr. 43, 44, 45, 46 to aϗ-, dϗ-, gϗ- and cϗ-minor are less recommendable, for in these, the major third of the finally reached tonic, seems more natura.
(In Nr. 42, however, the Dorian sixth c, in eϗ-minor, is quite natural and also correctly used for the modulation.)

div.head: 47) e-minor,
div.p: Tonic a-minor, which can be immediately used, as it is at the same time the sub-dominant of e-minor. (Cadence!)
[a I (= eIV), eII7 e V 64 e V7#| eI]

div.head: 48) b-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor, minor-dominant e-minor, which e-minor is used, as it is also the sub-dominant of b-minor. (Cadence!)
[aI, aV♮ (= hIV), hV64, h V#,| hI]

div.head: 49) f#-minor
div.p: Tonic a-minor; 1st inversion (chord of the sixth) of the diminished triad (g# b d) (aVII); translate this chord of the sixth (b d g#), to f#II (diminished triad g# b d [1st inversion] [in f#.minor] on the 2nd degree). (Cadence!)
[aI, aVII, (= fis II) fisV64, fisV#,| fisI

div.head: 50) c#-minor
div.p: Tonic a-minor; 1st inversion (chord of the sixth) of the diminished triad (g# b d) (aVII); use this chord of the sixth, which is also f#II (ist inversioin!); tonic f#-minor; use this f#-minor, which is at the same time the sub-dominant of c#-minor. (Cadence!)
[aI, aVII, (= fisII), fisI (= cisIV), cisV#,| cisI]

div.head: 51) g#-minor
div.p: Tionic a-minor; translate the chord of the sixth (b d g#) (aVII) f#II; dominant (C#-major) of f#-minor; use this C#-major, which is at the same time the chord of the Dorian sixth (c# e# g#) in g#-minor; dominant (D#-major) of g#-minor; tonic g#-minor. (Notice that the Dorian sixth must always go to the leading tone!)
[aI, aVII(=fisII), fisV#(=gisIV#,gisV ˟,| gisI]

div.head: 52) d#-minor
div.p: Tonic a-minor; dominant E-major; (1st inversion); use this chord of the sixth (g# b e), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in d#-minor. (Cadence!)
[aI, aV#(= disIV6♮4♮),dis V64, dis V˟, disI]

div.head: 53) a#-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; dominant E-major; 2nd superdominant ♭-major (1st inversion); use this chord of the sixth (d# f# b), which is also the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in a#-minor. (Cadence!)
[aI, aV#, aVv#(= aisIV6♮3#), aisV64, ais V˟,| ais I]

div.head: 54) e#-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; dominant E-major (1st inversion); use this chord of the sixth (g# b e), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in d#-minor; dominant (A#-major) of d#-minor; use this triad (a# cx e#), which is also the chord of the Dorian sixth in e#-minor; dominant (B#-major) or e#-minor; the chord of the seventh (diminished) on the 7th degree in e#-minor is used; tonic e#-minor.
NB. The diminished chord of the seventh (in minor on the seventh degree) always takes the place of the dominant!
[aI a V#(=dis IV6♮♮ dis IV˟(= eisIV˟) eis VII7| eisI]

div.head: 55) d-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; sub-dominant d-minor; use this d-minor, as the tonic in d-minor. (Cadence!)
[aI aIV(= dI) dII d V#| dI]

div.head: 56) g-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; use this a-minor (a c e), which is at the same time the chord of the Dorian sixth in g-minor; the dominant of g-minor (replaced by the 1st inversion of the diminished triad on the 7th degree in g-minor, i. e. a c f#); tonic g-minor.
[a I(= gIV5♮) g VII| gI

div.head: 57) c-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; sub-dominant d-minor; use this d-minor (d f a), which is at the same time the chord of the Dorian sixth in c-minor; dominant (G-major), tonic c-minor.
[aI,aIV(=cII5♮) c V7♮ cI]

div.head: 58) f-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d f b♭) in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d f b♭), which is at the same time the chord of the Dorian sixth in f-minor; dominant of f-minor (replaced by the diminished chord of the seventh on the 7th degree (e g b♭ d♭) of f-minor).
[aI aIV6♭(= fIV♮) fVII7fI]

div.head: 59) b♭-minor
div.p: Tonic a-minor; sub-dominant d-minor; relative to the tonic (C-major) of a-minor; use this C-major, which is also the 2nd super-dominant of b♭-minor; dominant (F-major) (with seventh e♭) of b♭-minor.
[aI aIV aIII(5♮)(= fVv♮) fV7♭| bI]

div.head: 60) e♭-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d f b♭) in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d f b♭), which is at the same time the 1st iversion of the dominant (B♭-major) of e♭-minor (with seventh; chord of the six-five).
[aI, aIV6♭,(= esV♮ es V7♭, | esI]

div.head: 61) a♭-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d f b♭) in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth, (d f b♭), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the 2nd super-dominant (B♭-major) of a♭-minor; dominant (with 7♭) (E♭-major) of a♭-minor.
[a I, aIV6♭(=as VV♮), asV7(♭)♮, asI]

div.head: 62) d♭-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d f b♭) in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d f b♭), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the 2nd super-dominant(B♭-major) of A♭-major; dominant (E♭-major with 7♭) of A♭-major; tonic A♭-major; use this A♭-major, which is at the same time the dominant (with 7♭) of d♭-minor.
[a I, a IV6♭(= AsVV),AsV7(♭) AsI(= desV(7♭)♮| desI]

div.head: 63) g♭-minor.
div.p: As in Nr. 62; use this A♭-major, which is at the same time the dominant of D♭-major; use this D♭-major (with 7♭), which is at the same time the dominant of g♭-minor.
[a I, aIV6♭(= AsVv), AsV(7♭), AI(=DesV7♭,| DesI (=gesV7♭♮), gesI]

div.head: 64) c♭-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; relative (F-major) to the sub-dominant (d-minor) of a-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (b♭ d♭ g♭) in F-major; use this chord of the sixth (v♭ d♭ g♭) , which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (G♭-major) of c♭-major; dominant (G♭-major with 7♭) of c♭-minor; tonic c♭-minor. (See Nr. 65.)
[aI, aVI(= FI), FIV6♭♭(= cesV♭, cesV7♭♭,| cesI]

div.head: 65) f♭-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; relative (F-major) to the sub-dominant (d-minor) of a-minor; use this F-major as tonic. (Also in Nr. 64 at the same place); chord of the Neapolitan sixth (b♭ d♭ g♭) in F-major; use this chord of the sixth (b♭ d♭ g♭) in F-major; use this chord of the sixth (b♭ d♭ g♭), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (G♭-major) of C♭-major; tonic C♭-major (with 7♭♭), which C♭-major is at the same time the dominant (with 7♭♭) of f♭-minor.
[aI, aVI(= FI),FIV6♭♭(=CesV), CesI(7♭♭),(= fesV7♭♭♭,| fesI]

div.head: 66) C-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; sub-dominant (d-minor); use this d-minor, which is relative to the sub-dominant (F-major) of C-major. (Cadence!)
[aI, aIV, (= CII) CV, CI]

div.head: 67) G-minor
div.p: Tonic a-minor; use this a-minor, which is relative to the sub-dominant (C-major) of G-major. (Cadence!)
[aI, a I,(= GII), GV64,GV(#),|G I]

div.head: 68) D-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; minor dominant (e-minor) of a-minor; use this e-minor, which is relative to the sub-dominant of D-major. (Cadence!)
[aI, aV♮,(= DII) DV6#4, DV(#)| DI]

div.head: 69) A-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; sub-dominant (d-minor) of a-minor; use this d-minor, which is at the same time minor sub-dominant in A-major. (Cadence!)
[aI, aIV,(=AIV♮), AV6#4, AV5#|AI]

div.head: 70) E-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; use this a-minor, which is at the same time minor sub-dominant in E-major. (Cadence!)
[aI(= EIV♮),( EV5##)EI]

div.head: 71) B-minor.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; minor dominant (e-minor) of a-minor; use this e-minor, which is at the same time minor sub-dominant in ♭-major. (Cadence!)
[aI, aV♮(=HIV♮)*), HV64, HV53,| HI]

div.head: 72) F#-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; minor dominant (e-minor) of a-minor; use this e-minor, which is at the same time minor sub-dominant in ♭-major; tonic ♭-major; use this ♭-major, which is at the same time sub-dominant in F#-major. (Cadence!)
[aI, aV♮(= HIV♮), HI(= FisIV) FisV| FisI]

div.head: 73) C#-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; chord of the Dorian sixth (f# a d) in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth (f# a d), which is at the same time chord of the Neapolitan sixth in C#-major. (Cadence!)
NB. Man beachte die Fürhrung des Basses von fis nach gis! (Dorsiche Sexte verlangt Führung nach aufwärts!)
[aI, aIII#,(= CisIV6♮♮), CisV7,| CisI]

div.head: 74) G#-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; dominant E-major; use the 1st inversion of this E-major (the chord of the sixth g# b e), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in D#-major; dominant (A#-major) of D#-major; tonic D#-major, is at the same time dominant in G#-major.
[a, aV#(= DisIV6♮♮,DisV˟,DI˟(= GisV),| GisI]

div.head: 75) D#-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; dominant E-major; use the 1st inversion of this E-major (chord of the sixth g# b e), which ist at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in D#-major; dominant (A#-major) of D#-major; tonic D#-major.
[aI, aV#, (=Dis IV6 ♮ ♮) DisV˟,DisI]

div.head: 76) A#-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; minor dominant (e-minor) of a-minor; use this e-minor, which is at hte same time the minor sub-dominant of ♭-major; tonic ♭-major; use the 1st inversion of this ♭-major (the chord of the sixth d# f# b), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapoitan sixth in A#-major. (Cadence!)
[a I aV♮,(= HIV♮)HI, (=AisIV6♮#) Ais˟V,|AisI]

div.head: 77) E#-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; minor dominant (e-minor) of a-minor; use this e-minor, which is at the same time minor sub-dominant in ♭-major; use the 1st inversion of this ♭-major (chord of the sixth d# f# b), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in A#-major; dominant (E#-major) of A#-major; use this E#-major as tonic, dominant (B#-major) of E#-major; tonic E#-major.
[aI, av♮, (= HIV♮) HI, (=AisIV6♮#) AisxV, | AisI]

div.head: 78) F-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; sub-dominant (d-minor) of a-minor; use this d-minor, which is relative to F-major. (Cadence!)
[aI, aIV (=FVI), FII7, FV, | FI]

div.head: 79) B♭-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; relative (F-major) to the sub-dominant (d-minor) of a-minor; use this F-major (with 7♭), which is at the same time the dominant of B♭-major.
[aI, aVI (=BV(7♭)), BI]

div.head: 80) E♭-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth ( d f b♭) in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d f b♭), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (B♭-major) of E♭-major.
[aI, aIV6♭ (=EsV), EsI]

div.head: 81) A♭-major.
div.p: Tonic a-major; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d f b♭) in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d f b♭), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the 2nd super-dominant (B♭-major) of A♭-major; tonic A♭-major.
[aI, aIV6♭ (= AsVV), AsV(7♭), AsI]

div.head: 82) D♭-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d f b♭) in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d f b♭), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (B♭-major) of e♭-minor; use this e♭-minor, which is relative to the subdominant (G♭-major) of D♭-major. (Cadence!)
[aI, aIV6♭ (= esV♮), esI (= DesII), DesV | DesI]

div.head: 83) G♭-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d f b♭) in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth, which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (B♭-major) of e♭-minmor; use this e♭-minor, which is relative to the tonic of G♭-major. (Cadence!)
[aI, aIV6♭ (= esV♮), esI (= GesVI), GesII, –GesV, GesI]

div.head: 84) C♭-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; relative (F-major) to the sub-dominant (d-minor) of a-minor; use this F-major as tonic; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (b♭ d♭ g♭) in F-major; use this chord of the sixth (b♭ d♭ g♭), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (G♭-major) of C♭-major; tonic C♭-major.
[aI, aVI (= FI), FIV6♭♭, (= CesV), CesI]

div.head: 85) F♭-major.
div.p: Tonic a-minor; relative (F-major) to the sub-dominant (d-minor) of a-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (b♭ d♭ g♭) in F-major, taken as the tonic; use this chord of the sixth (b♭ d♭ g♭), which is at the same time 1st inversion of the 2nd super-dominant (G♭-major) of F♭-major; dominant (C♭-major); tonic F♭-major.
[aI, aVI (= FI), FIV6♭♭ (= FesVV) | FesV, FesI]

div.head: 86) F#-major (f#-minor).
div.p: Tonic C♭-major; dominant (G♭-major) of C♭-major; use the 1st inversion of this G♭-major (chord of the sixth b♭ d♭ g♭), which is at the same time chord of the Neapolitan sixth in F-major; dominant (C-major) of F-major; use the 1st inversion of this C-major, (chord of the sixth e g c), which is at the same time chord of the Neapolitan sixth in E-major; tonic ♭-major, which ♭-major is at the same time sub-dominant in F#-major, or if modulating to f#-minor, chord of the Dorian sixth in f#-minor, chord of the Dorian sixth in f#-minor. (Cadence!)
[CesI, CesV (= FIV6♭♭), FV (= HIV6♮♮ HI (= FisIV | FisV(VII) FisI]
[CesI, CesV (= FIV6♭♭), FV (= HIV6♮♮ HI (= fisIV# | fisV#(VII#) fisI]

div.head: 87) C#-major (c#-minor).
div.p: Tonic C♭-major; dominant (G♭-major) of C♭-major; use the 1st inversion of this G♭-major (chord of the sixth b♭ d♭ g♭), as it is at the same time chord of the Neapolitan sixth in F-major; dominant (C-major) of F-major; use the 1st inversion of this C-major (chord of the sixth e g c), which is at hte same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in ♭-major; tonic ♭-major; dominant (F#-major) of ♭-major; use this F#-major, which is sub-dominant in C#-major (of chord of the Dorian sixth in C#-minor). (Cadence!)
[CesI, CesV (= FIV6♭♭ FV (= HIV6♮♮) HI | HV(= CisIV) CisV CisI]
[CesI, CesV (= FIV6♭♭ FV (= HIV6♮♮) HI | HV(= cisIV#) cisV# cisI]

div.head: 88) G#-major (g#-minor).
div.p: Tonic C♭-major; dominant (G♭-major) of C♭-major; use the 1st inversion of this G♭-major (chord of the sixth b♭ d♭ g♭), which is also the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in F-major; tonic F-major; relative (d-minor) to the tonic d-minor; use this d-minor as tonic; dominant (A-major) of d-minmor; use the 1st inversion of this A-major (chord of the sixth c# e a), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in G#-major (g#-minor). (Cadence!)
[CesI, CesV (= FIV6♭♭) FI, FVI (= dI) dV# (= GisIV6♮♮) | GisV GisI]
[CesI, CesV (= FIV6♭♭) FI, FVI (= dI) dV# (= gisIV6♮) | gisVX gisI]

div.head: 89) E-major (e-minor).
div.p: Tonic d♭-minor; dominant (A♭-major) of d♭-minor; use the 1st inversion of this A♭-major (chord of the sixth e c♭ a♭), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in G-major; dominant (D-major) of G-major; use this D-major, which is relative to the minor dominant (b-minor) of E-major (e-minor); minor sub-dominant (a-minor) of E-major (e-minor). (Cadence!)
[desI, desV♮, (= GIV6♭3♭ GV(= E♮VII) EIV♮ EV | EI]
[desI, desV♮, (= GIV6♭3♭ GV(= E♮VII) EIV♮ eV# | eI]

div.head: 90) ♭-major (b-minor).
div.p: Tonic d♭-minnor; dominant (A♭-major) of d♭-minor; use the 1st inversion of this A♭-major (chord of the sixth e c♭ a♭), which is also the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in G-major; dominant (D-major) of G-major; use this D-major, which is relative to the tonic of b-minor; dominant (F#-major) of ♭-major (b-minor); tonic ♭-major (b-minor).
[desI, desV♮ (= GIV6♭♭, GV (= hIII♮), hV# (=HV), HI]
[desI, desV♮ (= GIV6♭♭, GV (= hIII5♮), hV# (=HV), hI]

div.head: 91) F#-major (f#-minor).
div.p: Tonic d♭-minor; dominant (A♭-major) of d♭-minor; use the 1st inversion of this A♭-major (chord of the sixth c e♭ a♭), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in G-major; dominant (D-major) of G-major; relative (b-minor) to this D-major; use this b-minor, which is also minor sub-dominant of F#-major (f#-minor). (Cadence!)
[desI, desV♮ (= GIV6♭♭ GV, GIII (= FisIV♭), FisV, | FisI]
[desI, desV♮ (= GIV6♭♭ GV, GIII (= fisIV), fisV# (Fis#VII7♮), | fisI]

div.head: 92) C#-major (c#-minor).
div.p: Tonic d♭-minor; dominant (A♭-major) of d♭-minor; use the 1st inversion of this A♭-major (chord of the sixth c e♭ a♭), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in G-major; dominant (D-major) of G-major; use the 1st inversion of this D-major (chord of the sixth f# a d), which is also the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in C#-major (c#-minor). (Cadence!)
[desI, desV♮ (= GIV6♭♭), GV (=CisIV6♮♮), CisV, | CisI]
[desI, desV♮ (= GIV6♭♭), GV (=cisIV6♭♭), cisV#, | cisI]

div.head: 93) G#-major (g#-minor).
div.p: Tonic d♭-minor, dominant (A♭-major) of d♭-minor; use the 1st inversion of this A♭-major (chord of the sixth c e♭ a♭), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in G-major; dominant (D-major) of G-major; use this D-major as tonic; dominant (A-major) of D-major; use the 1st inversion of this A_major (chord of the sixth d# e a), which is also the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in G#-major (g#-minor).
[desI, desV♮ (= GIV6♭♭), GV (= DI), DV ≠ (GisIV6♮3♮), | GisV, GisI]
[desI, desV♮ (= GIV6♭♭), GV (= DI), DV = (gisIV6♮), | gisVX, gisI]

div.head: 94) D#-major (d#-minor).
div.p: Tonic d♭-minor; dominant (A♭-major) of d♭-minor; use the 1st inversion of this A♭-major (chord of the sixth e c♭ a♭), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in G-major; dominant (D-major) of G-major; change the D-major into d-minor and use this d-minor which is also sub-dominant in a-minor; dominant E-major; use the 1st inversion of this E-major (chord of the sixth g# b e), which is at the same time the chord of the Neapolitan sixth in D#-major (d#-minor). (Cadence!)
[desI, desV♮ (= GIV6𘁓♭), GV (GV♮ = aIV), aV# (DisIV6♮#), | DisV, DisI]
[desI, desV♮ (= GIV6𘁓♭), GV (GV♮ = aIV), aV# (disIV♮), | disVX, disI]

div.head: 95) B♭-major (b♭-minor).
div.p: Tonic a#-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d# f# b) in a#-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d# f# b), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (♭-major) of e-minor; tonic e-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (a c f), in e-minor; use this chord of the sixth (a c f), which is also the 1st inversion of the dominant (F-major) of B♭-major (b♭-minor).
[aisI, aisIV6♮#, (= eV#), eI, eIV6♮, | eIV6♮ (= BV), BI]
[aisI, aisIV6♮#, (= eV#), eI, eIV6♮, | eIV6♮ (= bV♮), bI]

div.head: 96) E♭-major (e♭-minor).
div.p: Tonic a#-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d# f# b) in a#-minor; use this chord of the sixth, which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (♭-major) of e-minor; tonic e-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (a c f), in e-minmor; use this chord of the sixth, which is also the 1st inversion of the 2nd super-dominant (F-major) of E♭-major (e♭-minor); dominant (B♭-major) of E♭-major (e♭-minor).
[aisI, aisIV6♮♮ (= eV) eI, eIV6♮ (= EsVV), | EsV, EsI]
[aisI, aisIV6♮♮ (= eV) eI, eIV6♮ (= esVV), | esV♮, esI]

div.head: 97) A♭-major (a♭-minor).
div.p: Tonic a#-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d# f# b), in a#-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d# f# b), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (♭-major) of e-minor; tonic e-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (a c f) in e-minor; use this chord of the sixth (a c f) which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (F-major) in B♭-major; tonic B♭-major; use this B♭-major, which is also 2nd super-dominant in A♭-major (a♭-minor); dominant (E♭-major); tonic A♭-major (a♭-minor).
[aisI, aisIV6♮# (=eV# eI, eIV6♮ (= BV), | BI (=AVV), AsV, AsI]
[aisI, aisIV6♮# (=eV# eI, eIV6♮ (= BV), | BI (=AVV), asV♮, asI]

div.head: 98) D♭-major (d♭-minor).
div.p: Tonic a#-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d# f# b) in a#-minor; use this chord of sixth (d# f# b), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (♭-major) of E-major; tonic E-major; minor sub-dominant (a-minor) of E-major; use this a-minor as tonic; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d f b♭) in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d f b♭), as ti is also the 1st inversion fo the 2nd super-dominant (B♭-major) of A♭-major; dominant E♭-major; tonic A♭-major; use this A♭-major, which is also the dominant of D♭-major (d♭-minor); dominant (A♭-major [with 7v]) of D♭-major (d♭-minor), tonic D♭-major (d♭-minor).
[aisI, aisIV6♮# (= EV) EI EIV♮ (= aI) | aIV6♭ (= AsVV) AsV AsI (= DesV) DesI]
[aisI, aisIV6♮# (= EV) EI EIV♮ (= aI) | aIV6♭ (= AsVV) AsV AsI (= desV♮) desI]

div.head: 99) G♭-major (g♭-minor).
div.p: Tonic a#-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth, (d# f# b), in a♭-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d# f# b), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (♭-major) of E-major; tonic E-major; use this E-major, which is also dominant in a-minor; tonic a-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d f b♭), in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d f b♭), which is also the 1st inversion of the 2nd super-dominant (B♭-major) of A♭-major; dominant (E♭-major) of A♭-major; use this A♭-major, which is at the same time the 2nd super-dominant in G♭-major (g♭-minor); dominant D♭-major; tonic G♭-major (g♭-minor).
[aisI, aisIV6♮# (= EV EI (= aV#) aI | aIV6♭ (= AsVV) AsV, AsI (=GesVV) GesV | GesI]
[aisI, aisIV6♮# (= EV EI (= aV#) aI | aIV6♭ (= AsVV) AsV, AsI (=gesVV) gesV♮ | gesI]

div.head: 100) G♭-major (ges-minor).
div.p: Tonic a#-minor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d# f# b) in a#-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d# f# b), which is at the same time the 1st inversion of the dominant (♭-major) of E-major; tonic E-major; use this E-major, which is also dominant in a-minor; tonic a-minmor; chord of the Neapolitan sixth (d f b♭) in a-minor; use this chord of the sixth (d f b♭) which is also the 1st inversion of the tonic B♭-major (in B♭-major); sub-dominant (E♭-major) of B♭-major; chord of the Neapoitan sixth (e♭ g♭ e♭) in B♭-major; use this chord of the sixth (e♭ g♭ c♭), as it is at the same time the 1st inversion of the tonic C♭-major (in C♭-major); dominant G♭-major; tonic C♭-major (c♭-minmor).
[aisI, aisIV6♮# (= EV) EI (= aV#) aI | aIV6♭ (= BI) BIV BIV6♭♭ (= CesI) CesV, | CesI]
[aisI, aisIV6♮# (= EV) EI (= aV#) aI | aIV6♭ (= BI) BIV BIV6♭♭ (= CesI) cesV♭, | cesI]
